frame.name: Roadways
frame.definition:
<def-root>This frame involves stable <fen>Roadway</fen>s which connect two stable <fen>Endpoints</fen>, the <fen>Source</fen> and the <fen>Goal</fen>. Being physical objects, these <fen>Roadway</fen>s may have <fen>Name</fen>s and <fen>Characteristic</fen>s; they are also made of a <fen>Material</fen>. They also cover ground, so they may have a <fen>Path</fen> or a <fen>Relative_location</fen> that the travel occurs in.
<ex> We crossed the <fex name="Material">brick</fex> <fex name="Roadway">road</fex>.</ex> <ex> I prefer to travel on <fex name="Roadway">highway</fex> <fex name="Name">I-80</fex>.</ex> <ex>This is the only <fex name="Roadway">highway</fex> <fex name="Endpoints">between Lodi and Sonoma</fex>.</ex> <ex> She dreaded turning onto the <fex name="Frequency_of_use">busy</fex> <fex name="Roadway">street</fex>.</ex></def-root>

FE.name: Roadway
FE.definition:
<def-root>The <fen>Roadway</fen> is the roadway that connects locations.
<ex>The <fex name="Road"><t>road</t></fex> runs between London and Manchester.</ex></def-root>

FE.name: Source
FE.definition:
<def-root>The <fen>Source</fen> is one of the <fen>Endpoints</fen> treated as a source.
<ex>The <t>road</t> <fex name="Src">from london</fex> to Glastonberry...</ex></def-root>

FE.name: Goal
FE.definition:
<def-root>The <fen>Goal</fen> is one of the <fen>Endpoints</fen> of the <fen>Roadway</fen> treated as a goal.
<ex>The <t>road</t> from London <fex name="Goal">to Glastonberry</fex>...</ex></def-root>

FE.name: Endpoints
FE.definition:
<def-root>The <fen>Endpoints</fen> are two (or more) named endpoints of the <fen>Roadway</fen>.
<ex>The <t>road</t> <fex name="EPs">between London and Glastonberry</fex>...</ex></def-root>

FE.name: Characteristic
FE.definition:
<def-root>The <fen>Characteristic</fen> is a characteristic(s) of the <fen>Roadway</fen>.
<ex>It was a <fex name="Char">long</fex>, <fex name="Char">winding</fex>, <fex name="Char">bumpy</fex> <t>road</t>.</ex></def-root>

FE.name: Name
FE.definition:
<def-root>The <fen>Name</fen> is the name of the <fen>Roadway</fen>.
<ex>We went down <fex name="Name">Abbey</fex> <t>road</t>.</ex></def-root>

FE.name: Path
FE.definition:
<def-root>This is the setting through which the <fen>Roadway</fen> goes.
<ex>The <t>tunnel</t> <fex name="Pat">through the mountains</fex>...</ex> </def-root>

FE.name: Use
FE.definition:
<def-root>The <fen>Use</fen> is the purpose of the <fen>Roadway</fen>.
<ex>This is the main <fex name="Use">traffic</fex> <t>artery</t> out of Berkeley.</ex></def-root>

FE.name: Direction
FE.definition:
<def-root>The <fen>Direction</fen> is the direction or directions the <fen>Roadway</fen> runs.
<ex> I-80 is an <fex name = "Direction">east-west</fex> <t>highway</t>.</ex></def-root>

FE.name: Relative_location
FE.definition:
<def-root>The <fen>Relative_location</fen> is where the <fen>Roadway</fen> is located.
<ex> The <t>highways</t> <fex name="rel">in California</fex> are the second-worst in the nation.</ex></def-root>

FE.name: Material
FE.definition: <def-root>The <fen>Material</fen> is what the <fen>Roadway</fen> is constructed from.</def-root>

FE.name: Frequency_of_use
FE.definition: <def-root>The <fen>Frequency_of_use</fen> is the state of the <fen>Roadway</fen> with regard to the number of people who are using the <fen>Roadway</fen> or typically use it.</def-root>

FE.name: Abundant_entities
FE.definition:
<def-root>The <fen>Abundant_entities</fen> are the entities which occupy the space denoted by the <fen>Roadway</fen>.
<ex> We passed an <fex name="Roadway">avenue</fex> <fex name="Abundant_entities">of boutiques and restaurants</fex>.</ex></def-root>

FE.name: Part
FE.definition:
<def-root>A subpart of the <fen>Roadway</fen>.
<ex>It was a <t>road</t> <fex name="Part">with too many twists and turns to count</fex>.</ex></def-root>

lexUnit.name: road.n
lexUnit.definition: COD: a wide way between places, especially one surfaced for use by vehicles.

lexUnit.name: path.n
lexUnit.definition: COD: a way or track laid down for walking or made by continual treading.

lexUnit.name: way.n
lexUnit.definition: COD: in place names a road, track, path, or street.

lexUnit.name: street.n
lexUnit.definition: COD: a public road in a city, town, or village, typically with buildings on one or both sides.

lexUnit.name: avenue.n
lexUnit.definition: COD: a broad road or path, especially one lined with trees.

lexUnit.name: artery.n
lexUnit.definition: COD: an important route in a traffic or transport system.

lexUnit.name: highway.n
lexUnit.definition: COD: .chiefly N. Amer. a main road.

lexUnit.name: expressway.n
lexUnit.definition: COD: chiefly N. Amer. an urban motorway

lexUnit.name: motorway.n
lexUnit.definition: COD: Brit. a road designed for fast traffic, consisting of two or more lanes in each direction and with restricted access and exits.

lexUnit.name: sidewalk.n
lexUnit.definition: COD: N. Amer. a pavement.

lexUnit.name: pavement.n
lexUnit.definition: COD: Brit. a raised paved or asphalted path for pedestrians at the side of a road. [Building]

lexUnit.name: underpass.n
lexUnit.definition: COD: a road or pedestrian tunnel passing under another road or a railway.

lexUnit.name: overpass.n
lexUnit.definition: COD: a bridge by which a road or railway line passes over another. [Engin]

lexUnit.name: railway.n
lexUnit.definition: COD: a track made of rails along which trains run.

lexUnit.name: railroad.n
lexUnit.definition: COD: North American term for railway.

lexUnit.name: route.n
lexUnit.definition: COD: the line of a road, path, railway, etc.

lexUnit.name: line.n
lexUnit.definition: COD: a railway track or route. [Railways]

lexUnit.name: crosswalk.n
lexUnit.definition: COD: a pedestrian crossing

lexUnit.name: bridge.n
lexUnit.definition: COD: a structure carrying a road, path, or railway across a river, road, etc.

lexUnit.name: tunnel.n
lexUnit.definition: COD: an artificial underground passage, as built through a hill or under a building or by a burrowing animal.

lexUnit.name: autobahn.n
lexUnit.definition: COD: a German, Austrian, or Swiss motorway.

lexUnit.name: lane.n
lexUnit.definition: COD: a narrow road, especially in a rural area.

lexUnit.name: track.n
lexUnit.definition: COD: a rough path or minor road.

lexUnit.name: trail.n
lexUnit.definition: COD: a beaten path through rough country.

lexUnit.name: boulevard.n
lexUnit.definition: COD: a wide street, typically one lined with trees.

lexUnit.name: course.n
lexUnit.definition: COD: n sing. the route or direction followed by a ship, aircraft, road, or river.

lexUnit.name: freeway.n
lexUnit.definition: COD: a toll-free highway

lexUnit.name: pathway.n
lexUnit.definition: COD: a path or its course.

lexUnit.name: roadway.n
lexUnit.definition: COD: the part of a road intended for vehicles, in contrast to the pavement or verge.

lexUnit.name: thoroughfare.n
lexUnit.definition: COD: a road or path forming a route between two places.

lexUnit.name: byway.n
lexUnit.definition: COD: a minor road or path.

lexUnit.name: cul-de-sac.n
lexUnit.definition: COD: a street or passage closed at one end.

lexUnit.name: driveway.n
lexUnit.definition: COD: a short private road leading to a house.

lexUnit.name: parkway.n
lexUnit.definition: COD: an open landscaped highway.

lexUnit.name: runway.n
lexUnit.definition: COD: strip of hard ground along which aircraft take off and land or a raised gangway extending into an auditorium, especially as used for fashion shows.

lexUnit.name: bypass.n
lexUnit.definition: COD: a road passing round a town to provide an alternative route for through traffic.

lexUnit.name: flyover.n
lexUnit.definition: COD: a bridge carrying one road or railway line over another.

lexUnit.name: rail.n
lexUnit.definition: FN: the railroad; train
